{{knowledge objective

|Item_parent_short=Infections osteo articulaires (IOA) de l'enfant et de l'adulte
|Rank=A
|Title=Knowing the clinical signs of acute septic arthritis
|Description=None
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Dr Florent Valour
|Order=10}}
- Location: monoarticular (80%), knee (50%) and hip most often

- Sudden onset

- [[Hyperthermia/fever SD-044|Fever/hyperthermia]] (50%)

- [[Joint pain SD-067|Joint pain]] and functional impotence (85%), analgesic attitude, [[Lameness SD-068|lameness]], [[Appearance of difficulty in walking SD-066|appearance of difficulty in walking]]

- Mobilisation of the extremely painful joint

- Joint effusion (patellar shock for the knee, for example) and inflammatory signs (clinically assessable for superficial joints)

- Systematic search for signs of severity (sepsis), a portal of entry, other secondary sites of bacteremia, signs of infective endocarditis, etc.

question.title: What is a common clinical sign of acute septic arthritis?
question.description: A symptom or finding that can indicate acute septic arthritis

option_a.title: Swelling of the affected joint
option_a.description: A possible symptom of acute septic arthritis

option_b.title: Fever over 1.5°C
option_b.description: A possible symptom of acute septic arthritis, but not always present

option_c.title: Limited range of motion
option_c.description: A possible symptom of acute septic arthritis, but not exclusive to it

option_d.title: Tenderness to palpation
option_d.description: A possible symptom of acute septic arthritis, but not always present

correct_option.title: Joint pain
correct_option.description: A common clinical sign of acute septic arthritis
